Joe Biden faced his first nomination defeat Wednesday evening when three moderate Democrats joined Republicans to tank Labor Department's Wage and Hour Division nominee David Weil.

Weil's defeat is also a major failure for the Biden administration and Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer – as the majority party leadership usually doesn't move forward nominees unless they think they have the votes to get them through.

The Labor Department's Wage and Hour Division is responsible for federal laws regarding occupational safety and health, wage and hour standards, unemployment benefits, reemployment services, and sometimes putting out economic statistics.
Weil faced heavy criticism by Republicans during the nomination process for the way he ran the agency within the Labor Department when he served in former President Barack Obama's administration.
Moderate Democrats faced pressure from Republicans to sink Weil's nomination, and the effort was fruitful as all three of the most moderate left-leaning senators voted against his confirmation.

Last year, the Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions (HELP) Committee deadlocked 11-11 on a vote to move Weil's nomination to the Senate floor.
During that confirmation process, Weil's nomination expired after it was sent to the Senate floor for a vote, leading the then-president to resend his nomination to the Senate floor.
During his time under Obama, Weil's critics lambasted him for policies like overtime pay, independent contractor classification and joint employment designations.
Every other nominee easily made it through with the razor thin Democrat majority – as Vice President Kamala Harris holds the power to break ties in the Senate.
Democratic Senators Joe Manchin of West Virginia and Kyrsten Sinema and Mark Kelly, both from Arizona, blocked Weil's nomination from moving forward.
This was the second time Weil was nominated to the post and is the first time a Biden nominee failed on the 50-50 split Senate floor.
Eventually he was advanced in a party-line vote when there was an absence at the time of Republican Kentucky Senator Rand Paul.
Every single Republican also voted against Weil's nomination, making the final vote count against invoking cloture 47-53.
Weil was confirmed by the Senate in April 2014 and served from then until the end of Obama's presidency in January 2017.
The likely next step is that Biden will have to regroup and put forward a different nominee for the post.
Weil was one of President Biden's most polarizing labor-related nominees.
